monumentInformation.title: Who Built It
details: The Great Wall was initially built by the Qin Dynasty under Emperor Qin Shi Huang in the 3rd century BCE.
It was expanded and reinforced by later dynasties, notably the Han Dynasty (206 BCE–220 CE) and the Ming Dynasty (1368–1644 CE).

monumentInformation.title: Where It Is Located
details: The Great Wall stretches across northern China, covering approximately 21,196 kilometers (13,171 miles).
It spans from Shanhaiguan in the east to Jiayuguan in the west, crossing mountains, deserts, and grasslands.

monumentInformation.title: When It Was Built
details: Construction of the earliest sections began in the 7th century BCE during the Warring States period.
The most well-preserved sections, seen today, were built during the Ming Dynasty between the 14th and 17th centuries CE.

monumentInformation.title: Who Is It Protected By
details: The Great Wall was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1987 for its historical significance.
It is protected and maintained by the National Cultural Heritage Administration of China and various preservation organizations.

monumentInformation.title: Why It Was Built
details: The Great Wall was built primarily to protect China from invasions by nomadic tribes and military incursions from the north.
It also served as a means of border control, trade regulation, and communication along the Silk Road, symbolizing the strength and unity of ancient China.
